'''''"Little Eva"''''' was a [[USAAF]] [[Consolidated B-24 Liberator]] which, returning from a bombing mission, got lost and crashed having exhausted its fuel supply on 2 December 1942 north-west of [[Burketown, Queensland|Burketown]], Queensland (near the [[Gulf of Carpentaria]]).
The crew had taken to their parachutes before the crash. The survivors, now in two groups, set out on foot. Two of the crew travelled east and came across people after twelve days. The other party travelled westerly, with the only surviving member being found some five months later.
==Crash== The aircraft, part of the 321st Squadron, [[90th Operations Group|90th Bombardment Group]] based at [[Iron Range National Park|Iron Range]] was returning with four other B-24s from a bombing raid on a Japanese troop convoy about 80 km north of [[Buna, Papua New Guinea]]. "Little Eva" lost touch with the other aircraft and returned to the base on its own. A severe thunderstorm disabled the radio, causing the flight to lose its way and run out of fuel. Lieutenant Norman Crosson, the pilot, gave orders to bail out. Most of the crew members parachuted to safety, however one was killed when his parachute snagged on the aircraft and another who did not jump was killed when the plane crashed at about 2:45am near the Burriejella waterhole.
==Survival== Although the crew had been instructed to meet at the crash site, only Crosson and Sergeant Loy Wilson arrived there. The other survivors had decided to head for the coast about {{convert|24|km|mi|abbr=on}} away. Both groups of survivors believed they were on the east coast of [[Cape York Peninsula]] and close to [[Cairns, Queensland|Cairns]].
Crosson and Wilson had extremely little food and water. They walked east to what they felt should be the east coast of Cape York and quite by chance this route took them almost straight to Escott Station, 15 km west of [[Burketown, Queensland|Burketown]], where they arrived after a trek of some 60 km on 14 December 1942. Exhausted and with badly blistered feet, they were driven to the four-bed Burketown hospital for medical attention and flown back to Iron Range a week later. Their rescue sparked a search for the other men which would continue for some five months. The missing men were Staff Sergeant Grady Gaston, 2nd Lieutenant Arthur Speltz, 2nd Lieutenant Dale Grimes, 2nd Lieutenant John Dyer, and two other unaccounted crew members. Their resources consisted of two .45 calibre pistols, a few bars of chocolate, a jungle knife, a fish hook and line, and some matches.
After the crash Gaston's party travelled in a westerly direction until they reached the Gulf of Carpentaria and then followed the shoreline. They were fortunate enough to shoot a young bullock on their fourth day out, gorged themselves on as much meat as they could and pressed on. Concerned about carrying unnecessary weight, they took no meat with them. A day later they discarded their pistols as being rusty and useless. Heading north-west along the beach, they were forced to swim across a number of rivers—managing to avoid the crocodiles common in those waters.<ref name="Dunn OZCrashes"/>
==Search and rescue== On 15 December 1942 a large search party consisting of seven men of the [[2/1st North Australia Observer Unit|North Australia Observer Unit]] (NAOU), fifteen [[Volunteer Defence Corps (Australia)|Volunteer Defence Corps]] (VDC) members, a local policeman and two [[Australian Aborigines|aborigine]] trackers set out from Escott Station to find the crash site.
The officer heading the search was Lieutenant Stan Chapman of the NAOU and he made his headquarters at Burketown. Five days into the search he enlisted the help of Ian Hosie, a [[Royal Flying Doctor Service of Australia|Flying Doctor]] and soon located the wreckage. Here they found six parachutes and two charred corpses which they buried at the site. Lieutenant Frank Comans of the NAOU set out with a small party to follow the tracks of the survivors. This they managed to do for more than 130 km. The wet conditions made for difficult tracking particularly at stream crossings and the trail was finally lost at Settlement Creek near the border between Queensland and [[Northern Territory]].
The survivors found a shack on 24 December where they made a base. Grimes, the bombardier, was drowned in Robinson River when the current took him out to sea and he was too weak to swim back. His body was later recovered. Lt Dyer died on 10 February and Speltz (co-pilot) in the night of 24/25 February. Grady Gaston, the ball turret gunner, was rescued on 23 April 1943 when he was discovered by [[Stockman (Australia)|stockmen]] looking for stray cattle and taken over time to [[Cloncurry, Queensland|Cloncurry]]. From there he was collected by the USAAF on 11 May.
==Documentary== In 1988, [[Les Hiddins]] visited the crash location and filmed the wreckage as part of his [[Bush Tucker Man]] show (series 1, episode 7).
In 1994, Film Australia produced a one-hour documentary about the crash called ''Aeroplane Dance''.
A feature film is being developed by Fact Not Fiction Films on the 'Little Eva' story.<ref name="FactNotFictionFilms LittleEva"/>
